column4: I'm having some problems taming the HAL beast... anyone around who could help?
whats wrong with HAL?
gnome-volume-manager is a little too aggressive in mounting partitions on my USB stick, AFAICS HAL is the way to prevent it... but I can't get it to work
aggressive?, in what way?
I sec
it mounts the device (dev/sdb in my case) as well as both partitions (/dev/sdb{1,2})... how do I convince it to leave /dev/sdb unmounted?
I dont follow, usb sticks use fat16!
I have a USB stick that I ran cfdisk on... two partitions, one vfat, one ext3
dont know then, sound like soemthing you did yourself

yupp, sure did... but how do I get HAL to respect my whishes? I can use it to change the "label" it uses to mount it (i.e. the name it shows on the desktop), but I just can't stop the mounting altogether :(
even there were only one partition, how would I turn off the mounting of it (i.e. not mounting a specific USB stick), I still want all other sticks to mount...
ok
you could change the policies in /etc/hal
how?
i'm not to familier with it, there is a file in /fdi
yes, I've been playing with it... I've managed to use it to change the label (volume.label), but I don't know what to change in order to prevent gnome-volume-manager to mount the damn thing
tell it not not mount drives, it that what you mean?
nope not quite, tell it not to mount a specific device
http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software_2fhal
ah, the HAL spec, thanks!
thanks, I've gotten some more ideas of how to do it... just have to wait until I'm at _my_ computer again, tomorrow
